3 Literature This version: 2021-03-12 3.1 List of papers - Classic Akerlof (1970): Must read about asymmetry of information. Fama and French (1997) Fama and Jensen (1983a) Fama and Jensen (1983b) La Porta et al. (1998): Must read about Law and Finance. Jensen and Meckling (1976): The origins of Agency conflicts and Corporate Governance. Jensen (1986): Corporate Governance classics. Markowitz (1952): The origins of portfolio. Modigliani and Miller (1958): Capital structure classics. Myers and Majluf (1984): Important for capital structure decisions. 3.2 List of papers - Corporate Finance Almeida et al. (2011): Nice application of DiD in Finance. Strebulaev and Yang (2013): Why some firms go zero-leveraged? 3.3 List of papers - Governance Bertrand and Mullainathan (2003): The paper that suggests that managers like a quite life. Black et al. (2017): About construct validity of Governance Boyd, Gove, and Solarino (2017): A must read paper about methodological issues in CG research. Chen, Dong, and Lin (2020): A nice paper about institutional investment and CSR performance: they have a sound RDD application. Dickinson (2011): A way to identify a firms stage of life using cash flows. Schiehll and Martins (2016): About the different associations of Governance and Investor Protection. 3.4 List of papers - Open Science RACs editorials: I recommend all RACs Editorials since 2018 about Open Science, Open data and related topics (https://rac.anpad.org.br/index.php/rac) Babin et al. (2020): Replication methods in academic research. Beugelsdijk, Witteloostuijn, and Meyer (2020): The JIBS editorial about Open Science Harvey (2017): discusses the publication of significant results. Read to understand what is the publication bias. Harvey (2019): A discussion about replications. Spiegel (2019): About replication and open data. Mendes-Da-Silva and Cerqueira Leal (2021): What is Salami Science? Raaij (2018): About Data Reuse 3.5 List of materials - Econometrics Abadie, Diamond, and Hainmueller (2010): An example of Synthetic Control. Adams (2017): A cool list about empirical problems in governance (and finance) research. Angrist and Pischke (2008): Good to learn about causality methods. Angrist and Pischke (2014): Easier to read than previous one. I use this one in classes. Atanasov and Black (2016): Good Review about causal methods. Bascle (2008): Also easy to read review about endogeneity and methods. Bertrand, Duflo, and Mullainathan (2004) Brooks (2019): Book with nice examples and lots of codes. Bowen, Frésard, and Taillard (2017): Important to see the development of causal methods. Cappelleri and Trochim (2015): Introduction to RDD. Gow, Larcker, and Reiss (2016): Good review about causal methods. Gormley and Matsa (2014): This is here so I remember to read (didnt read yet). Jiang (2017): A discussion about instrumental variables. Kahn and Whited (2018): Identification is not causality, and vice-versa. Lindner, Puck, and Verbeke (2019): Some ideas aboout multicollinearity. McLean, Zhang, and Zhao (2012): Good article to learn how to make interpretations of coefficients and marginal effects. They are very didactic. Murray (2006): Nice examples of instruments Petersen (2009): Discussion about standard-errors in Finance. Reeb, Sakakibara, and Mahmood (2012): Easy to reed review about endogeneity in International Business. Roberts and Whited (2013): Good review about causal methods. Roodman (2009b): Important to estimate GMM in stata. Roodman (2009a): Important to estimate GMM in Stata. Schiozer, Mourad, and Martins (2020): A tutorial about Diff-in-Diff, with open data and open code. Stuart (2010) Wasserstein and Lazar (2016): About p-value and the importance of not using a single metric to assess the quality of a model. Wooldridge (2019): The basic must-to-read book about econometrics. 3.6 List of books - Finance Ehrhardt and Brigham (2012): ótimo livro para graduação e MBAs, mas não gosto da forma da tradução. Berk and Demarzo (2013): Meu livro preferido para graduação e MBAs. No entanto, a versão boa é a inglês.
